column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0016] Common methods used to prevent radiation degradation in performance for integrated circuits are: 1) design special radiation tolerant die, 2) screen each part for radiation tolerance, or 3) shield the package or the platform.
#Text=There are tradeoffs with each of these methods.
#Text=The first example usually is the most radiation tolerant.
#Text=Here the die is specially designed to be radiation tolerant.
#Text=However, this method is both time consuming and expensive to produce since the part must be redesigned to incorporate radiation hardening techniques.
#Text=Examples of this method include U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=This method delays the time to market such that these radiation hardened devices are usually 2 to 3 generations behind the current commercial technological advances in both size and capabilities.
#Text=There are additional penalties in limited marketability and demand for the product.
#Text=The result is a higher cost from low volume productions of the die.

#Text=The end result, is that this method produces; 1) a more expensive product that is 2) technologically behind current commercially available microelectronics, 3) frequently with slower speed and 4) less capability.
#Text=Additionally because of the limited market for these products, frequently they are not available at all.
#Text=[0017] The second method involves testing each part or die lot in the hopes that the die will meet the mission radiation requirements.

#Text=This could be an expensive process because of the large amount of testing that would be required and the low probability of success in finding an inherently radiation tolerant die that meets the mission requirements.
#Text=This problem is compounded for Multi-chip Modules in that all the die required in the package need to be radiation tolerant.

#Text=This is not only extremely restrictive on the design and expensive because of the amount of testing but it is highly unlikely that all the required die will be found that will meet the radiation requirements of the mission.
#Text=[0018] The third method involves shielding the part.
#Text=This method includes either shielding the entire satellite, subsystem or individual part.
#Text=Shielding the satellite or subsystem carries extreme weight and size penalties that generally make this solution cost prohibitive.

#Text=The spacecraft has some inherent shielding the skin and spacecraft components, however this is very difficult to model and generally doesn't provide adequate shielding for all parts and directions.
#Text=[0019] An example of system level shielding is U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 4,833,334, which is incorporated by reference as if fully set forth herein, describes the use of a protective box to house sensitive electronic components.
#Text=This box is partially composed of a high atomic weight material to effectively shield against x-rays.
#Text=However this approach has the serious disadvantage off adding substantial bulk and weight to electronic circuit assemblies protected in this manner.
#Text=Moreover, it would be expensive to provide this type of protection to individual integrated circuits as manufacturing custom boxes for each circuit configuration would be costly.
#Text=Similarly U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 5,324,952, follows a method of shielding components.
#Text=If shielding is required the better method is to shield only the components that require shielding.
#Text=[0020] One method of shielding individual components is know as spot shielding.
#Text=With this method, a small shield is attached to the surface of the package.
#Text=However this method does not provide effective 3-dimensional shielding protection.
#Text=Additionally, the external shield is generally thermally mismatched to the package, and increases the size and weight of the package.
#Text=Often a bottom spot shield cannot be used due to the inability to accommodate a fixed lead length.
#Text=The spot shield also has no mechanical support except the adhesive used to attach it to the surface of the package.
